review.abstract: This paper presents a trust computation for international relations and its calculus, which related to Bayesian inference, Dempster Shafer theory and subjective logic. We proposed a method that allows a trust computation which is previously subjective and incomputable. An example of case study for the trust computation is the United States of America Great Britain relations. The method supports decision makers in a government such as foreign ministry, defense ministry, presidential or prime minister office. The Department of Defense (DoD) may use our method to determine a nation that can be known as a friendly, neutral or hostile nation.

metadata.title: A Mathematical Trust Algebra for International Nation Relations Computation and Evaluation

sections.text: This manuscript presents a confidence calculation for international relations and its calculation, based on Bayesian conclusions, Dempster-Shafer theory, and subjective logic. We have proposed a method that enables a confidence calculation that was previously subjective and unpredictable. A case study of trust calculation is the relationship between the United States of America and the United Kingdom. The method supports decision makers in government areas such as the State Department, Department of Defense, Presidential or Prime Minister's Office. The Department of Defense (DoD) can use our method to determine a nation that may be known as friendly, neutral, or hostile.

sections.heading: Introduction
sections.text: In our previous work (Mohd Anuar Mat Isa et al., 2012a, 2012b), we mentioned the need for a "trust model" in Common Criteria (CC), in which we model international relations between nations using a calculation model we call trust algebra. The proposed method will enable a confidence calculation that was previously subjective and unpredictable.

sections.heading: Related Work
sections.text: There are many trust definitions expressed in natural languages. In order to enable confidence calculation in computer systems, the trust definitions must be communicated in a measurable or quantifiable notation, such as in statistical representations. The first attempt to represent trust in statistical notations was made by (Dempster, 1967). Dempster demonstrated a probability measurement intended to define a higher and lower probability for multi-layered mapping. The probability measurement is a generalization of the calculation in Bayesian theory. His statistical scheme is adopted by (Shafer, 1979, 1976) and represents an elegant method for calculating trust. Many researchers later (1980-1995) treated both works as the basis for a concrete trust calculation, which they began to call the Dempster-Shafer theory in the early 1980s (Shafer, 1). This manuscript is a draft version. The final version will be published in a respected journal. You can contact the main static (contact @) of the trust theory for further information on 1997.

sections.heading: Conclusion
sections.text: In this paper, we have modeled a trust algebra for international relations. The purpose of the trust algebra method is to enable trust calculations and trust modelling. So far, there is no such method to perform trust calculations for international relations, which are subjective and unquantifiable. Furthermore, we have presented the international relations between the US and the UK as a case study to demonstrate the proposed method in a real scenario.
